results.title: Energy: towards the age of abundance
results.creator_credit: Peter Thurling, Douglas Leiterman, Philip S. Hobel, ACI Films and Hobel-Leiterman Productions
results.brief_description: As traditional energy sources dwindle we must look to such alternatives as nuclear fission, tidal power and solar energy.

results.title: Energy: the dilemma. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Provides a well-balanced overview of the current world energy crisis. Looks at the various energy options which are available (oil, coal, natural gas, nuclear) and the problems asociated with the use of each of these power resources.

results.title: Energy: new sources. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Thomas Smith, Robert Churchill and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Looks at potential alternatives to our present dependence on fossil fuels, such as solar energy, nuclear fusion, geothermal and synthetic fuels. The future of the world’s energy supplies is cast in an optimistic light.

results.title: Energy: less is more. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Thomas Smith, Robert Churchill and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Looks at various ways to make more efficient use of the world’s dwindling supplies of fossil fuels: transportation systems, industrial applications, and building construction. Includes a case study of energy conservation in Davis County, California.

results.title: Energy from the sun
results.brief_description: Animated and live-action sequences are used to explain the water cycle and to show how solar energy is transformed, transmitted through space, utilised by man and by plants, and stored for future use. Shows the work of scientists in converting the sun’s energy into industrial power. Includes an exploratory visit to the sun by means of telescopic stop-motion photography.

results.title: Energy from the atom
results.creator_credit: Atomic Energy of Canada and Crawley Films
results.brief_description: This film offers audiences a clear illustration of how an atomic reactor produces electricity. Special features of the Canadian CANDU (Canada Deuterium Uranium) system are explained: on-power refuelling; the use of natural uranium; the use of heavy water as moderator. CANDU is recognized internationally as a leader in the search for new sources of energy.

results.title: Energy everlasting
results.brief_description: Everyone knows that oil won’t last forever. The search for new forms of renewable energy is increasing. This film looks at some of the ways that are being used to explore the options available. In Indonesia and the Phillipines photo voltaics provide electricity for homes. In Sweden, biomass and hydroelectricity play an increasing role, and in other parts of the world, wind and wave power are playing their part. The costs of these systems are as yet untested in a harsh fiscal world but, in the next thirty years, some of these fledgling technologies will come more and more to the fore.

results.title: Endotracheal anaesthesia
results.creator_credit: Margaret Thomson, ICI (GB) and Realist Films
results.brief_description: Without a clear airway the administration of a general anaesthetic is impossible. This film shows how endotracheal anaesthesia overcomes this difficulty by intubation of the larynx. The advantages of endotrachael anaesthesia are summarised.
